metadata.title: SWENG 805 Software Project Management – Penn State Great Valley

headings.h2: Apply Systems Thinking to Tackle Complex Project Challenges

paragraphs: This course offers a comprehensive exploration of technical project management. Technical projects often grapple with the challenges of exceeding schedules and budgets. We delve deep into understanding the roots of these challenges while equipping aspiring project managers with invaluable techniques and methodologies to navigate, mitigate, and conquer the risks that jeopardize project triumph.
The goal of this course is to empower you with the knowledge and tools essential for effective technical project management.
The objective of this course is to provide theoretical foundations and hands-on experience in Natural Language Processing. After successfully completing this course, you will be able to:
The textbook for this course is available online at no cost to Penn State students:

E-Book Option: An online version of your text is available at no cost as a Penn State Library E-Book. You can access the E-Book through the Library Resources link on the course navigation. You may choose to use the E-Book as an alternative to purchasing a physical copy of the text. For questions or issues, contact the University Libraries Reserve Help (UL-RESERVESHELP@LISTS.PSU.EDU).
Additional required readings are available online:
Proctored Exams- Mid-term and final exams will be proctored via Honorlock (online proctoring software)
Grades will be based on the following scale:

There will be discussion forums associated with most lessons. You are required to log on to every discussion forum and to post at least one direct answer or original observation related to the assigned theme and/or questions. You are also required to have a discussion with at least one of your classmates during each discussion forum unless otherwise instructed (please make it clear to whose comments you are responding).

Your instructor will evaluate your performance every week and provide feedback (as a group and/or on an individual basis) on how you are doing. Your formal grade for discussion forum performance will be calculated based on the number and timeliness of postings you make and the quality of your comments (e.g., degree of advanced thinking, quality of communication).

Lessons will contain one or more Portfolio Entry sections that you must complete. The purpose of the Portfolio Entries is twofold. First, it is intended to make you think, reflect, and evaluate the lesson content with respect to your own experiences. I want you all to find the content meaningful to your own situation and for you to fully evaluate your personal, group, and organizational performance in light of the material we examine.
There will be 3 quizzes, each will consist of 5 questions. You will have an opportunity to take each twice. Canvas will keep your highest score.
There will be one midterm and one final exam during the course, both of which will be proctored. Electronic and paper copies of the exam materials (books and course notes) are permitted during exams.

The midterm and final exam may be proctored via Honorlock (online proctoring software). The proctoring software uses your computer’s webcam or other technology to monitor and/or record your activity during exams.  Electronic and paper copies of the exam materials (books and course notes) are permitted during exams. The proctoring software, Honorlock, may be listening to you, monitoring your computer screen, viewing you and your surroundings, and recording any activity (including visual and audio recordings) during the proctoring process. By enrolling in this course, you consent to the use of the proctoring software, including but not limited to any audio and/or visual monitoring which may be recorded.
*Syllabus subject to change
Some commonly used estimation techniques are listed below. Consider which techniques are used in your organization.

Much of this course is devoted to improving management skills, but how does one go about developing their leadership ability or potential? The first thing to understand is that leadership is from the inside-out. You will learn about the importance of the different phases of becoming a leader.
Let’s look at the standard systems engineering lifecycle.
This course will provide you with a thorough introduction to Software Project Management, including:
During this course you will expand your knowledge of the lesson topics each week.

In this lesson, you will build a strong foundation in understanding the diverse responsibilities of a project manager. Delve into the essential skills needed to steer projects successfully, from coordinating tasks to leading teams and driving results.

Explore the wide-ranging duties of a project manager and discover how to effectively balance technical, organizational, and interpersonal roles. You’ll examine the traits that distinguish successful project managers and learn to adapt your approach to various project demands.

Study different management theories and leadership styles, and learn how to apply these frameworks to improve project outcomes. You’ll gain insight into how to inspire teams, make informed decisions, and navigate the complexities of managing technical projects.
By the end of this lesson, you will have a comprehensive understanding of what it takes to thrive as a project manager, equipped with both theoretical insights and practical strategies.

This lesson focuses on building and managing teams effectively, including navigating challenging personalities and fostering group cohesion. Learn strategies for turning dysfunction into high performance.

Discover techniques for handling team members who may disrupt productivity, and learn how to cultivate a positive environment that supports effective teamwork. You’ll explore methods for identifying and addressing behavioral challenges.

Examine the characteristics of successful teams and apply best practices to enhance collaboration. Understand the dynamics of different personality types and leverage their strengths to achieve common goals.
By the end of this lesson, you will be well-prepared to lead teams effectively, navigating interpersonal challenges while driving productivity.
In this lesson, you will gain a deep understanding of antipatterns—recurring obstacles in software project management—and how to prevent them from derailing project success.
Identify behaviors and practices that undermine project progress, such as micromanagement or inadequate planning. Learn to spot these issues early and implement strategies to avoid them.
Explore ways to transition from harmful practices to productive approaches. You’ll discover how to turn common pitfalls into opportunities for growth and improvement within your team or organization.
Completing this lesson will equip you with the skills to identify and correct counterproductive behaviors, leading to more efficient project management.
In this lesson, you will learn advanced strategies for negotiating and resolving conflicts, essential skills for any project manager dealing with diverse stakeholders.
Develop negotiation techniques that enable you to achieve win-win situations. Learn how to adapt your strategies based on the context and the personalities involved.

Gain insights into conflict resolution techniques that help manage disagreements productively. You’ll explore various conflict styles and discover how to select the most appropriate approach for each situation.
By the end of this lesson, you will have a toolkit of strategies to address conflicts and negotiate solutions that satisfy all parties involved.
This lesson provides critical knowledge for creating reliable project schedules and using Earned Value Management (EVM) to track project performance.
Understand how to create realistic schedules that account for all project phases and potential risks. Learn techniques to identify critical paths and allocate resources efficiently.
Discover how EVM can help you assess whether a project is on track, under budget, or needs adjustments. You’ll learn to use performance metrics to make data-driven decisions.
Completing this lesson will enable you to plan projects more accurately and use performance data to steer projects toward successful completion.
In this lesson, you will explore various estimation techniques to forecast project effort, time, and cost more accurately.

Examine widely used models such as COCOMO II and learn how to apply them in different project contexts. You’ll gain insights into the limitations of estimation techniques and how to mitigate potential errors.
Discover strategies for overcoming common estimation challenges, such as unrealistic assumptions or scope changes. Learn to refine estimates as new information becomes available.
By the end of this lesson, you will be equipped with advanced skills to make more precise project estimates and manage risks associated with forecasting.
This lesson introduces you to systems thinking, enabling you to approach project management holistically and address interconnected issues effectively.

Develop the ability to view projects as dynamic systems where various elements interact. You’ll explore strategies for identifying root causes and understanding how changes in one area can affect the entire system.

Expand your problem-solving toolkit by considering diverse viewpoints and leveraging stakeholder input. Learn to balance conflicting priorities while maintaining focus on the overall project objectives.
By completing this lesson, you will be able to approach project challenges with a systems-oriented mindset, enhancing your ability to deliver successful outcomes.

Studying software project management opens doors to a multitude of career opportunities and significantly enhances professional prospects in the tech industry! Equipped with an understanding of project management principles tailored to the software development lifecycle, individuals can pursue roles as project managers, software development managers, product managers, or even transition into leadership positions within technology-driven organizations.

Mastering software project management cultivates crucial skills such as effective communication, strategic planning, risk management, and team leadership, all of which are highly sought after across various industries. As technology continues to evolve and permeate every aspect of business and society, the demand for skilled software project managers remains consistently high, ensuring a robust and promising career trajectory for those with expertise in this field.
A software project manager may be involved in a diverse range of projects, spanning different industries and applications. Example of possible projects include:

Regardless of the specific project, the software project manager’s role is to oversee all aspects of the project lifecycle, from initial planning and requirements gathering to implementation, testing, and deployment, while ensuring that the project is completed on time, within budget, and to the satisfaction of stakeholders.
Penn State Great Valley © 2025

Understand the framework and techniques for managing software projects
Demonstrate understanding management and leadership theories.
Contextualize project management and its role in soft engineering.
Apply the concepts of negotiation, estimation, and project planning

Colin J. Neill, Phillip A. Laplante, Joanna F. DeFranco.  Antipatterns: Managing Software Organizations and People, Second Edition (Applied Software Engineering Series). [Hardcover] 2011.  ISBN-10: 1439861862     ISBN-13: 978-1439861868
Project Management Institute. Agile Practice Guide (2017), Project Management Institute. ProQuest Ebook Central.
Project Management Institute (2017) A guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK guide) (6th ed.) Project Management Institute
Project Management Institute (2021) A guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK guide) (7th ed.) Project Management Institute
The Project Manager: Roles and Responsibilities
Team Personnel: Difficult people, effective teams
The Role of the Project Manager
Leadership in Action: Analyze case studies and apply leadership concepts to project scenarios, developing strategies for effective project management.
Self-Assessment of Skills: Reflect on your existing project management skills and identify areas for growth.
Portfolio Development: Begin building your project management portfolio with exercises focused on skills and tools essential for success.
Conflict Resolution Techniques: Practice strategies for addressing and mitigating conflicts within teams.
Leadership Assessment: Explore your leadership style through the Keirsey Temperament Sorter and reflect on how it affects team dynamics.
Portfolio Integration: Expand your project management portfolio with entries on leadership and team dysfunction.
Analyzing Antipatterns: Evaluate real-world examples of antipatterns and discuss how they could have been prevented.
Personal Reflection: Conduct a self-assessment to identify any antipatterns in your own management style and develop a plan for improvement.
Portfolio Development: Add insights on recognizing and overcoming antipatterns to your project management portfolio.
Practical Negotiation Exercise: Participate in a negotiation activity to practice the skills learned, aiming for a mutually beneficial agreement.
Conflict Style Analysis: Assess your preferred conflict management style and explore how to apply it effectively.
Portfolio Addition: Update your project management portfolio with reflections on negotiation and conflict handling experiences.
Project Scheduling Exercise: Work through scheduling scenarios to identify potential delays and propose solutions.
EVM Analysis: Apply EVM concepts to project case studies and evaluate performance outcomes.
Portfolio Update: Add reflections on project scheduling and EVM practices to your project management portfolio.
Estimation Exercise: Practice applying estimation methods to project scenarios and compare the outcomes.
Self-Assessment: Reflect on your approach to estimation and identify areas for improvement.
Portfolio Entry: Document your experiences with estimation techniques in your project management portfolio.
The Beer Game Simulation: Participate in a team exercise to experience systems thinking in action and understand the impact of supply chain dynamics.
Reflective Analysis: Engage in self-study to explore multiple perspectives on complex project scenarios.
Portfolio Development: Document your learning experiences with systems thinking and their application to real-world projects.

Development of a Mobile Banking App: A software project manager could lead a team in developing a mobile banking application for a financial institution. This project would involve gathering requirements from stakeholders, designing the user interface and user experience (UI/UX), implementing security features, integrating with banking systems, conducting testing, and ultimately launching the app to customers.

Implementation of an Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) System: In a large organization, a software project manager might be tasked with implementing an ERP system to streamline business processes and improve operational efficiency. This project would involve selecting the appropriate ERP software, customizing it to fit the organization’s needs, migrating data from legacy systems, training users, and providing ongoing support post-implementation.

Upgrade of an Electronic Health Records (EHR) System: In a healthcare setting, a software project manager might oversee the upgrade of an existing electronic health records system to comply with regulatory requirements or to incorporate new features and functionalities. This project would involve coordinating with healthcare providers, IT staff, software vendors, and possibly regulatory agencies to ensure a smooth transition with minimal disruption to patient care.
